slide.title: Trusting = Risk !
slide.notes: A risk management process Unique to humans
slide.notesNormalized: a risk management process unique to humans
slide.notesHtml:
A risk management process

Unique to humans
slide.text: Trusting = Risk !
● Measure of risk in investments Annualized rate of return SUCCESSFUL INVESTOR CHOICES ● ● ● ● conservative aggressive

slide.notes: Take them through these slides about parenting for trustworthiness about everything: money, internet use, not sharing family $$ info, etc
slide.notesNormalized: take them through these slides about parenting for trustworthiness about everything: money, internet use, not sharing family $$ info, etc
slide.notesHtml: Take them through these slides about parenting for trustworthiness about everything: money, internet use, not sharing family $$ info, etc
slide.text: How far to trust my child Safe! DANGER ! HIGH RISK PARENT’S DILEMMA No trust Complete trust but NO LEARNING
DANGER ! HIGH RISK OPPORTUNITY WASTED PARENT’S DILEMMA Child’s reliability not reliable very reliable How much to trust my child Safe, NO LEARNING productive human capital
RELATIONSHIP DEVELOPMENT productive human capital Other’s reliability not reliable very reliable How much to rely on Other Safe, but USELESS

RELATIONSHIP DEVELOPMENT Other’s reliability not reliable very reliable How much to rely on Other Safe, but USELESS risk (test) a little responsibility/authority a little more a little more a little more trained and reliable partner a little more

GRANTING FREEDOM TO YOUTH Youth’s Proven Responsibility not yet reliable very reliable Reliance on Youth’s Responsibility safe, but no development risk (test) a little responsibility/authority a little more a little more a little more mutually trusted a little more Elder ADULT Younger ADULT

slide.title: Trust the Process !
slide.notes: Which works both ways — Employees and owners, parents and children, current board and successor candidates, etc Our instinct is to TRUST — that’s the default. It’s actually being cautious that’s against ou instincts. Reaction to being disappointed is to go all the way to the opposite extreme, of distrust. We want trusting our kids to be easy — but there’s no reason it should be. There’s too much to acquire culturally rather than instinctively, for it to be easy
slide.notesNormalized: which works both ways — employees and owners, parents and children, current board and successor candidates, etc our instinct is to trust — that’s the default. it’s actually being cautious that’s against ou instincts. reaction to being disappointed is to go all the way to the opposite extreme, of distrust. we want trusting our kids to be easy — but there’s no reason it should be. there’s too much to acquire culturally rather than instinctively, for it to be easy
slide.notesHtml:
Which works both ways —

Employees and owners, parents and children, current board and successor candidates, etc

Our instinct is to TRUST — that’s the default. It’s actually being cautious that’s against ou instincts. Reaction to being disappointed is to go all the way to the opposite extreme, of distrust.

We want trusting our kids to be easy — but there’s no reason it should be. There’s too much to acquire culturally rather than instinctively, for it to be easy
slide.text: Trust the Process !
Lover’s reliance on Other ( vulnerable) OPPORTUNITY WASTED COURTSHIP productive relationship Other’s reliability not reliable very reliable play it safe DANGER ! HIGH RISK

productive human capital ENTERPRISE AT RISK: inadequate new leaders ENTERPRISE AT RISK: no qualified successors LEADERSHIP SUCCESSION PROCESS Successors’ proven readiness to lead not reliable very reliable Authority invested in successor(s) Safe, but USELESS

educated to potential Child or young adult doomed to fail OPPORTUNITY WASTED SCHOOL PROMOTION: AGE or ACHIEVEMENT? School achievement below grade level above grade level Advance to next level educationally wise, but UNPOPULAR
no-threat citizen DANGER to society WASTE of public funds and human life PAROLE BOARD DECISION Likelihood of recidivism high very low never parole early parole Safe, but COSTLY

added human capital for US DANGER to society opportunity costs and WASTE of public funds IMMIGRATION POLICY Immigrant value security threat or social liability no threat, useful assets bar the door open door Safe (?) but COSTLY
South Korea’s concessions OPPORTUNITY WASTED “TRUSTPOLITIK” (President Park Geun-hye) productive relationship North Korea’s behavior aggressive cooperative play it safe DANGER ! HIGH RISK

slide.notes:
Denial on both sides.
Give me some examples of your concerns (this didn’t work well, I had to give examples: How much allowance at age 12? At what age should a trust distribute? At what age tell kids what they are “worth” (and please don’t phrase it like that) Should parents buy a condo for a college student? Pay for married daughter’s home? Answers: It all depends — where you are on the trusting process, in general and specifically, is one of the factors on which it depends
slide.notesNormalized:
denial on both sides.
give me some examples of your concerns (this didn’t work well, i had to give examples: how much allowance at age 12? at what age should a trust distribute? at what age tell kids what they are “worth” (and please don’t phrase it like that) should parents buy a condo for a college student? pay for married daughter’s home? answers: it all depends — where you are on the trusting process, in general and specifically, is one of the factors on which it depends
slide.notesHtml:
Denial on both sides.

Give me some examples of your concerns (this didn’t work well, I had to give examples:

How much allowance at age 12?

At what age should a trust distribute?

At what age tell kids what they are “worth” (and please don’t phrase it like that)

Should parents buy a condo for a college student?

Pay for married daughter’s home?

Answers: It all depends — where you are on the trusting process, in general and specifically, is one of the factors on which it depends
slide.text: Basic Financial Maturity Knowledge plus ? Confidence + Caution Beware wishful DENIAL

slide.notes: When you make rules about $$ (like those the panel mentioned), you aren’t merely teaching about money — you’re teaching about responsibility in general and you are also teaching that when you make a Deal, you mean it.
slide.notesNormalized: when you make rules about $$ (like those the panel mentioned), you aren’t merely teaching about money — you’re teaching about responsibility in general and you are also teaching that when you make a deal, you mean it.
slide.notesHtml: When you make rules about $$ (like those the panel mentioned), you aren’t merely teaching about money — you’re teaching about responsibility in general and you are also teaching that when you make a Deal, you mean it.
slide.text: Family Rules must be: Clear Written Consistent with parents’ values Enforceable (and consistently enforced)

slide.notes:
“Money doesn’t spoil children, parents do (sorry for paraphrasing NRA)
How would you structure a Deal for the child to earn something you don’t want them to have? Answer: Don’t.
There’s nothing wrong with using $$ to manipulate children as long as they get something they want and something you want them to have.
A debit card is a Deal.
Hope’s car is a common example. And I didn’t do the same for my son!
slide.notesNormalized:
“money doesn’t spoil children, parents do (sorry for paraphrasing nra)
how would you structure a deal for the child to earn something you don’t want them to have? answer: don’t.
there’s nothing wrong with using $$ to manipulate children as long as they get something they want and something you want them to have.
a debit card is a deal.
hope’s car is a common example. and i didn’t do the same for my son!
slide.notesHtml:
“Money doesn’t spoil children, parents do (sorry for paraphrasing NRA)

How would you structure a Deal for the child to earn something you don’t want them to have? Answer: Don’t.

There’s nothing wrong with using $$ to manipulate children as long as they get something they want and something you want them to have.

A debit card is a Deal.

Hope’s car is a common example. And I didn’t do the same for my son!
slide.text: Financial Deals must be: Clear Written Consistent with parents’ values Enforceable (and enforced)

slide.text: Advanced Course: AMD and its Antidotes

slide.title: Mike’s Deal
slide.notes: Explain that it’s just a specific example, the reasoning I use. Encourage questions, objections: “I see some anxioous or restless faces”
slide.notesNormalized: explain that it’s just a specific example, the reasoning i use. encourage questions, objections: “i see some anxioous or restless faces”
slide.notesHtml:
Explain that it’s just a specific example, the reasoning I use.

Encourage questions, objections: “I see some anxioous or restless faces”
slide.text:
Mike’s Deal Parents agree to:
Loan enough to reconnect phone and internet and cover this month’s bills. Mom will do Mike’s banking. Mike agrees to:
Mom paying monthly bills first out of each paycheck. Then repay a minimum of $100 back to parents. Completed when:
Loan repaid. All bills are paid up. Shared goal:
Mike doing his own banking and bill paying. Mike living within his means.
